channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: Mark Bailey, Unknowable Minds & Susan Schneider, Artificial You
channel.desc: Professors Mark Bailey and Susan Schneider look at the future of artificial intelligence. Books and Books in Coral Gables, Florida, hosted this event.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: Sally Satel et al., The Free Inquiry Papers
channel.desc: American Enterprise Institute senior fellow Sally Satel and contributors to the book The Free Inquiry Papers talk about academic freedom in the Unites States and what they say is a the decline of free inquiry in American higher education.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: Gerard Toal, Oceans Rise Empires Fall - Why Geopolitics Hastens Climate Catastrophe
channel.desc: Government and international affairs professor Gerard Toal argues that the assumptions of geopolitics leads countries into competition over resources instead of cooperation to address climate change.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: Emily Feng, Let Only Red Flowers Bloom - Identity and Belonging in Xi Jinping's China
channel.desc: NPR's Emily Feng reports on how some in China are pushing back against efforts to control free expression.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: Source Booksellers - 2025 Publishers Weekly Bookstore of the Year
channel.desc: Source Bookselllers owner Janet Webster Jones discusses the independent bookstore in Detroit's Midtown district and what she's learned over more than two decades in the bookselling business.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: John McWhorter, Pronoun Trouble
channel.desc: Columbia University linguistics professor John McWhorter talks about the use and evolution of language and argues that the controversy over pronoun usage in America is largely overblown.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: Steve Olson, Eruption
channel.desc: Steve Olson recalls the volcanic eruption at Mount St. Helens in southwestern Washington on May 18, 1980, which resulted in the deaths of 57 people and $1 billion in damage.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: After Words
channel.desc: University of Michigan law professor Leah Litman makes the case for why she believes the Supreme Court isn't making rulings based on legal principles.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: John McWhorter, Pronoun Trouble
channel.desc: Columbia University linguistics professor John McWhorter talks about the use and evolution of language and argues that the controversy over pronoun usage in America is largely overblown.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: Steve Olson, Eruption
channel.desc: Steve Olson recalls the volcanic eruption at Mount St. Helens in southwestern Washington on May 18, 1980, which resulted in the deaths of 57 people and $1 billion in damage.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: After Words
channel.desc: University of Michigan law professor Leah Litman makes the case for why she believes the Supreme Court isn't making rulings based on legal principles.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: Murray Carpenter, Sweet and Deadly - How Coca-Cola Spreads Disinformation and Makes Us Sick
channel.desc: Journalist Murray Carpenter argues that Coca-Cola uses the same tactics as the tobacco industry to obscure the health effects of soda. Book Passage Bookstore in San Francisco hosted this event.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: Mark Bailey, Unknowable Minds & Susan Schneider, Artificial You
channel.desc: Professors Mark Bailey and Susan Schneider look at the future of artificial intelligence. Books and Books in Coral Gables, Florida, hosted this event.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: Sally Satel et al., The Free Inquiry Papers
channel.desc: American Enterprise Institute senior fellow Sally Satel and contributors to the book The Free Inquiry Papers talk about academic freedom in the Unites States and what they say is a the decline of free inquiry in American higher education.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: Gerard Toal, Oceans Rise Empires Fall - Why Geopolitics Hastens Climate Catastrophe
channel.desc: Government and international affairs professor Gerard Toal argues that the assumptions of geopolitics leads countries into competition over resources instead of cooperation to address climate change.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: Emily Feng, Let Only Red Flowers Bloom - Identity and Belonging in Xi Jinping's China
channel.desc: NPR's Emily Feng reports on how some in China are pushing back against efforts to control free expression.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: Source Booksellers - 2025 Publishers Weekly Bookstore of the Year
channel.desc: Source Bookselllers owner Janet Webster Jones discusses the independent bookstore she founded in Detroit's Midtown district in 2002 and what she's learned over more than two decades in the bookselling business.
